label: Constituent Part
definition: A physically discernable part of a compound specimen that has a distinct proportion and role relative to the parent object and a discrete determination based on physical and chemical characteristics. All parts of a compound specimen are unified through physical attachment or other unifying criteria.
usage_note: Each Constituent Part belongs to one and only one Constituent Part Type (Rock, Fossil, Mineral, etc). The shared characteristic among all records that utilize the Mineralogy Extension is they must belong to the Constituent Part Type, Mineral defined as an element or a chemical compound that is normally crystalline and that has been formed as a result of geological processes (Nickel 1995).
source: Term nomenclature adopted primarily from GeoSciML (4.1 and 3.2), Basic Formal Ontology, and the Geoscience Ontology. The terminology is based on Miller III, W. (2003). Paleobiology of complex trace fossils. Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology, 192(1-4), 3-14.
note: Specimens comprised of and defined by Constituent Parts unified through physical attachment or other unifying criteria are referred to as Compound Specimens

label: Material Entity ID
definition: Globally unique identifier of the parent dwc:MaterialEntity. Establishes a relationship with an Material Entity record
usage_note: Required to establish a relationship between a parent material entity record (specimen-level) with zero to many child mineral records (mineral-level)

label: Constituent Part ID
definition: A unique identifier for an instance of a ConstituentPart.
usage_note: In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the dwc:constituentPartID globally unique. Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier. Constituent Part ID is used to construct the relationship between a specimen (compound object) and mineral (constituent part).

label: Constituent Part Type
definition: Term belonging to an upper-level, generalized classification scheme of geoext:ConstituentPart
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a shared controlled vocabulary. A Constituent Part belongs to only one Constituent Part Type.
note: The formal name assigned to a geoscience collection is traditionally based on the predominant Constituent Part Type of specimens in the collection or the field of science associated with the respective part type (e.g., Mineral Collection or Mineralogy Collection).

label: Proportion
definition: The qualitative or quantitative fraction the geologic specimen is composed of the constituent part
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as https://cgi.vocabs.ga.gov.au/object?uri=http%3A//resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/proportionterm

label: Role
definition: Specifies the relationship between a constituent part and its parent geologic specimen
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as https://cgi.vocabs.ga.gov.au/object?uri=http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/compoundmaterialconstituentpartrole
note: The role defines the relationship between a constituent part and its parent compound object.

label: Name
definition: The designation of a mineral by a linguistic expression including both informal (verbatim) and formal (classifications) types

label: Cataloged Name
definition: A human-readable lexical label assigned at the specimen level for cataloging and other administrative purpose
usage_note: Cataloged names are typically assigned for activities such as cataloging, physical organization, and exhibit presentation. They are often compond names with a predicate.

label: Name
definition: A human-readable lexical label assigned to a mineral includes both informal (e.g., variety, synonym) and formal (classification) forms
examples: Quartz | Smoky Quartz | Muscovite | Garnet Group
usage_note: The name defined in the first object is considered the preferred name
note: For linked data and semantic purposes, the classification name is the skos:prefLabel and all other informal names are skos:altLabel

label: Name Identifier
definition: An identifier for the set of dwc:MineralName information. May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier. Name ID is used to establish the one to many relationship between dwc:Mineral and dwc:MineralName that allows the assignment of multiple names to a single mineral in a specimen

label: Language
definition: Language of the name
usage_note: Recommended practice is to use either a non-literal value representing a language from a controlled vocabulary such as ISO 639-2 or ISO 639-3, or a literal value consisting of an IETF Best Current Practice 47 language tag.

label: Mineral Name Published In
definition: A reference to the publication in which the name is derived, provided as formal citations or URI to an external resources
examples: Strunz | H. & Nickel | E.H. (2001): Strunz mineralogical tables. Schweizerbart | Stuttgart | 869 p. | Gaines | R.V. | Skinner | H.C. | Foord | E.E. | Mason | B. | Rosenzweig | A. (1997): Danaâ€™s new mineralogy. Wiley & Sons | New York | 1819 p.
usage_note: Narrower scope than dwc:namePublishedIn
note: The term 'mineral' is prepended to term in order to distinguish them from similarly named terms in Darwin Core

label: Classification Code
definition: Alphanumeric pattern that adheres to a defined encoding scheme that identifies a particular term in a classification scheme
usage_note: Classification codes are specific to a classification system and conform to a xkos:notationPattern
note: Classification codes conform to a specific pattern specific to the scheme. See xkos:notationPattern

label: Name Type
definition: A term belonging a categorization scheme for organizing names based on usage and concept lineage
examples: Variety | Synonym | Classification | Historical | Group Name
usage_note: Ideally, terms in this field are derived from a enumerated domain. See Gavryliv (2023) for a detailed breakdown of informal, alternate names.
note: Best suited for enumerated domains, but careful quantification is challenging with very specific definitions.

label: Name Confirmation Technique
definition: Analytical technique utlized to confirm the identity of a mineral
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary

label: Name Remarks
definition: Statements that provide further information on any part of a mineral name, especially information not captured elsewhere in the mineral name class

label: Material Assertion
definition: An Assertion is a statement about an entity and the process by which it was ascertained. An Assertion can be made at one time and assert the state of something at another time. Examples: a measurement, an observation, an annotation.

label: Specimen Description
definition: Comments or notes about the specimen (physical object) especially those that distinguish the specimen from similar materials in a collection
examples: Showpiece | Historically valuable | Extraordinary composition | Two generations of quartz
usage_note: See broader concept http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/occurrenceRemarks for additional usage notes

label: Verbatim Size
definition: The verbatim size of a specimen as originally described in primary source material
examples: 10 cm x 5 cm X 5 cm | largest diameter 16 cm | width 3 inches

label: Measured Width in Millimeters
definition: Measured width of specimen reported numerically in millimeters
usage_note: Height, width, and depth measurements should measured along perpendicular axes from a single shared point of origin

label: Measured Height in Millimeters
definition: Measured height of specimen reported numerically in millimeters
usage_note: Height, width, and depth measurements should measured along perpendicular axes from a single shared point of origin

label: Measured Depth in Millimeters
definition: Measured depth of specimen reported numerically in millimeters
usage_note: Height, width, and depth measurements should measured along perpendicular axes from a single shared point of origin

label: Verbatim Mass
definition: The original reported verbatim mass includes original units of measurement

label: Measured Mass In Grams
definition: Mass of specimen measured in grams

label: Mineral Description
definition: Comments or notes about the mineral instance, especially those that distinguish the mineral from similar materials in a collection
examples: Pink fluorite on quartz | Lengenbachite on sugar-grained dolomite | Epitaxial growth on kyanite | Doubly terminated quartz crystals
usage_note: The scope of this term is strictly to a mineral within the context of the specimen. Specimen level descriptions belong in the related term, specimenDescription. Sibling concept to http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/occurrenceRemarks

label: Maximum Axial Dimension
definition: Maximum axial dimension of largest crystal measured in millimeters

label: Associated Minerals
definition: List of secondary minerals associated with a mineral in a specimen

label: Aggregate Form
definition: Observable crystal shapes of an assemblage of minerals
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary

label: Crystal Habit
definition: A general term for describing the outward appearance of a mineral
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. For a given type of crystal, the habit may vary from locality to locality depending on environment of growth.

label: Crystal Form
definition: Geometric shape of a crystal
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary
note: Alternate definition: A crystal form is a set of crystal faces that are related to each other by symmetry.

label: Twinning Law
definition: Short description of any physically discernable twinning
examples: Dauphine twinning/Dauphine Law | Japan twinning/Japan Law | Brazil twinning/Brazil Law

label: Color
definition: The intrinsic color of a mineral under natural light
usage_note: Here, color is caused by the absorption, or lack of absorption of different wavelengths of natural light by a particular mineral

label: Exsolution Texture
definition: A brief description of textures formed by exsolution
examples: Ilmenite lamellae in olivine | Clinopyroxene lamellae along the (100) plane of orthopyroxene | Antiperthite exsolution.

label: Cleavage
definition: Type of breakages along a plane of weakness, especially those parallel to crystal faces

label: Luster
definition: The reflection of light from the surface of a mineral, described by its quality and intensity
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary

label: Inclusions
definition: Short description of any inclusions present within a mineral that includes the phase and physical characteristics
examples: Star-shaped rutile needles in quartz | Needles of tourmaline in quartz (blue quarz) | Fluid inclusions (liquid bubble and single crystal) in quartz
note: Inclusions are defined as small foreign bodies (solid, liquid, or gas) within the physical bounds of a material commonly trapped during formation

label: Luminescence Description
definition: The type and nature of light emitted from the mineral upon receiving energy from an external source.
examples: Green fluorescence | Pink under short wave UV light
usage_note: Includes all types of luminescence including fluorescence (all wavelengths) and phosphorescence. Recommended best practice is to use nomenclature in part based on the source of energy, or the trigger for the luminescence.

label: Alteration Description
definition: A description of any observed changes in the composition of a mineral brought about by physical or chemical processes related to changes in the physical or chemical environment.
editorial_note: Definition adopted from the concepts under term sources

label: Hazard
definition: Properties that describe sources of potential damage, harm, or adverse health effects on something or someone.

label: Hazard Type
definition: Term that belongs to a hazard classification scheme based on a set of unique characteristics and negative health outcomes.
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary

label: Hazard Remarks
definition: General remarks regarding the hazard type within the scope of the specific collection object

label: Conservation
definition: Processes, protocols, and techniques established for the purpose of the protection and preservation of a mineral or specimen
editorial_note: Changed level to Specimen to simplify usage. If conservation is associated with a specific mineral in a compound specimen, then that should be declared in the description

label: Treatments
definition: Description of any processes or curatorial actions taken specifically to mitigate damage
usage_note: Includes both proactive and reactive actions

label: Handling Requirements
definition: A summary of the procedural requirements employed to preserve and protect the specimen during physical interaction
examples: Handle with gloves | Not to be taken ourt of storage medium | delicate | avoid contact with direct sunlight

label: Damage Remarks
definition: A general description of any material changes to a mineral which is perceived to have negatively affected an itemâ€™s value-defining aspects.
examples: Due to oxidation and hydration of the pyrite in the coal, the sample has largley decayed to a coal powder with some larger coal pieces | Some terminations broken off | Attached label not legible (or torn, or covered)
source: Royce, K., Baars, C., & Viles, H. (2021). Defining Damage and Susceptibility, with Implications for Mineral Specimens and Objects: Introducing the Mineral Susceptibility Database. Studies in Conservation, 68(3), 298â€“317. https://doi.org/10.1080/00393630.2021.2015947

label: Chemistry
definition: Properties that describe the chemical composition of a geological material (mineral)

label: Measured Formula
definition: A concise expression of the chemical composition of a mineral that shows the number of atoms of each element in a molecule, their spatial arrangement, and their linkage to each other.
source: Defintion adopted from Structural Formula (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/MS_1000867) in the Mass spectrometry ontology

label: Chemistry Remarks
definition: General remarks about the chemical and isotopic composition of a mineral

label: Measured Chemistry Source
definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of resources associated with the reported measured chemistry described specifically enough to allow anyone in the future to use the same resources.
examples: Novak, G. A., & Gibbs, G. V. (1971). The crystal chemistry of the silicate garnets. American Mineralogist: Journal of Earth and Planetary Materials, 56(5-6), 791-825.
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use full bibliographic citations, global unique identifiers, or resolvable and persistent URIs. See the broader concept http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/associatedReferences

label: Mineralogical Analysis Protocol
definition: The technique utilized to determine the chemical composition or crystallography of a mineral
examples: Wet Chemistry | X-ray fluorescence | Electron probe microanalysis | Scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy | X=ray diffraction
usage_note: Acronyms should be avoided even for widely recognized annotations. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as https://vocabs.ardc.edu.au/viewById/650

label: Geologic Context
definition: Geological information, such as stratigraphy, that qualifies a region or place.

label: Geologic Province
definition: Extensive named region with a similar geologic history throughout or similar structural, petrographic, or physiographic features in which the dwc:Location occurs
examples: Coastal Plain | Piedmont | Blue Ridge | Colorado Plateaus | Basin and Range | Dalradian Metamorphic Belt
source: Neuendorf, K. K. (2005). Glossary of geology. Springer Science & Business Media.

label: Lithodemic Unit
definition: Geologic unit that lacks stratification, primarily comprised of intrusive, deformed, and (or) metamorphosed rock, and characterized by irregularly mixed lithology or highly complicated structural relations.
examples: Catalina Core Complex (named unit) igneous complex | injection complex | metamorphic complex | basement complex
usage_note: Due to the unstructured nature of complexes, both named units and lithological descriptive terms are acceptable values.

label: Geologic Event
definition: An identifiable event during which one or more geological processes associated with the formation of a geological specimen or act to modify an existing geological specimen.
examples: Sevier orogeny | Alleghanian orogeny | Alpine orogeny | Variscan orogeny | Waipounamu Erosion surface | Vredefort impact

label: Mineral Sequence
definition: A list of minerals in a specimen ordered in a manner that illustrates the relative timing of mineral formation within a specimen.
examples: Sphalerite > Quartz > Pyrite | Calcite > Quartz > Sphalerite > Pyrite
usage_note: The list should only contain minerals that belong to a readily identifiable sequence of formation. Therefore, a list may contain a subset of the minerals in a specimen. Minerals that formed in-situ with one another are separated by a plus. Minerals that formed in the sequence are separated by a greater than symbol.

label: Tectonic Units
definition: The combination of all tectonic unit names for the rock from which the dwc:MaterialEntity was collected.
examples: Upper Helvetic, Wildhorn Nappe Complex, Sublage Nappe
usage_note: Recommended best practice is to use an authoritative tectonic unit lexicon such as the Tectonic Map of Switzerland (TK500)

label: Location
definition: A spatial region or named place.

label: Sampled Feature
definition: The type of physical feature, both naturally-occuring and anthropogenic in origin, sampled during a sampling event (dwc:Event) at a dwc:Location
examples: float | mine dump | mine/quarry pit | outcrop | erratic boulder
usage_note: A sampled feature has a type and optional name that distinuishes the feature from similar entities. Sampled features can be anthropogenic (roadcut, borehole) or naturally occurring (outcrop).

label: Named Place
definition: The full, unabbreviated name of a geographic location not otherwise categorized by a dwc:Location property that is naturally occurring or anthropogenic in origin within a historical, administrative, or cultural context in which dcterms:Location occurs.
examples: Susanna Mine | Craigleith Quarry | Red Cloud Mine
usage_note: Only the names of locations anthropogenic in origin should use the namedPlace property. For naturally-occurring locations, please use terms in dwc:GeologicContext (e.g., geologicProvince) class. For named places represented as URIs or global unique identifiers, please use dwc:locationID.

label: Is Type Locality
definition: Whether or not the dwc:Location is the same locality where the original material used for the formal definition of the mineral species originated.

label: ChronometricAge
definition: An approximation of a temporal position (in the sense conveyed by https://www.w3.org/TR/owl-time/#time:TemporalPosition) that is supported via evidence.

label: Chronometric Age Geologic Process
definition: The name of the geologic process associated with the chronometric age
